p.s: Teacher: Brilliant!
Teacher: So far, all the examples we saw were multisyllabic words like Vater, Onkel, Mädchen
Teacher: These words break into 2 syllables - Fa-ter, On-kel, Mäd-chen
Teacher: We showed ownership for these examples, by adding s to get des Vaters, des Onkels, des Mädchens
Teacher: But for monosyllabic words like Mann, Buch, Kind, we add an es, instead of just s
Teacher: So it becomes des Mannes, des Buches, des Kindes
Teacher: Now how would you say, "the eyes of the child"?
Student: Die Augen, des Kindes
Teacher: So how will you say - "The eyes of the child are green"?
Student: Die Augen, des Kindes, sind Grün
Teacher: Very nice. Now try saying "The eyes of the child are green because her mother comes from Germany"?
Student: Die Augen des, Kindes sind grün, weil, ihre Mutter, aus Deutschland, kommt
Teacher: Great job. How would you say "The head of a dog, is big"?
Student: Der Kopf, eines Hundes, ist groß
Teacher: Perfect. Try saying "The house of my friend, is small"?
Student: Das Haus, meines Freundes, ist klein
Teacher: Good. How can one say, "I am going to the house of my friend"?
Student: Ich gehe, zum Haus, meines Freundes
Teacher: The verb for, "to lose", is verlieren
Student: Verlieren?
Teacher: Yes
Teacher: Lost in German, is verloren
Teacher: It is just like the English word, forlorn. Forlorn means to be abandoned, or pitifully sad, lonely
Teacher: So how can one say, "We are lost"?
Student: Wir sind verloren
Teacher: Now how would you say "The keys of the car are lost"?
Student: Die Schlüssel, des Autos, sind verloren
Teacher: Great job!
